mn45:3.3: This view is said to be a cause for lower rebirth at [an3.113:1.5](), an addiction at [an3.156:1.6](), and an extreme at [ud6.8:5.4]().
mn45:3.5: _Moḷibaddha_ (“head-band”) appears as a bejeweled decoration for lay folk at [mil6.1.3:1.3]() and [mil6.4.2:4.2](), and with a list of garbs for ascetics at [mil5.1.6:12.5](). The Sanskrit _maulibandha_ appears in a few later texts in the same sense. None of these sources, however, clarify who these fancy wanderers might be.
mn45:4.6: Acc. to Ven Nyanatusita,'Thus it makes sense that the deity says that the termites could eat it. Perhaps even the whole seed was eaten since the Maloo Creeper, a member of the legume family, has a hard woody seed. It is eaten by forest people in India, supposedly after removing the skin. Termites do not carry away seeds like ants would do, they eat things at the spot. Besides this the seed is quite large. http://gardentia.net/2014/03/23/bauhinia-climber/ Thus udrabheyyuṁ is probably the right reading. It is supported by the commentary which glosses it as khādeyyuṁ.
